Module Contents¶

class jpt.trees.Node(idx: int, parent: Union[None, DecisionNode] = None)¶

Wrapper for the nodes of the jpt.learning.trees.Tree.

Parameters:

  • idx (int) – the identifier of a node

  • parent (jpt.learning.trees.Node) – the parent node

consistent_with(self, evidence: jpt.variables.VariableMap) → bool¶

Check if the node is consistend with the variable assignments in evidence.

Parameters:

evidence (VariableMap) – A VariableMap that maps to singular values (numeric or symbolic)

class jpt.trees.DecisionNode(idx: int, variable: jpt.variables.Variable, parent: DecisionNode = None)¶

Represents an inner (decision) node of the the jpt.learning.trees.Tree.

Parameters:

  • idx (int) – the identifier of a node

  • variable (jpt.variables.Variable) – the split feature name

consistent_with(self, evidence: jpt.variables.VariableMap) → bool¶

Check if the node is consistend with the variable assignments in evidence.

Parameters:

evidence (VariableMap) – A VariableMap that maps to singular values (numeric or symbolic)

  • parent (jpt.learning.trees.Node) – the parent node

applies(self, query: jpt.variables.VariableMap) → bool¶

Checks whether this leaf is consistent with the given query.

evidence (VariableMap) – A VariableMap that maps to singular values (numeric or symbolic)

class jpt.trees.JPT(variables, targets=None, min_samples_leaf=0.01, min_impurity_improvement=None, max_leaves=None, max_depth=None, variable_dependencies=None)¶

Joint Probability Trees.

Implementation of Joint Probability Tree (JPT) learning. We store multiple distributions induced by its training samples in the nodes so we can later make statements about the confidence of the prediction. has children Node.

Parameters:

  • variables ([jpt.variables.Variable]) – the variable declarations of the data being processed by this tree

  • min_samples_leaf (int or float) – the minimum number of samples required to generate a leaf node

  • variable_dependencies (None or Dict from variable to list of variables) – A dict that maps every variable to a list of variables that are directly dependent to that variable.

infer(self, query, evidence=None, fail_on_unsatisfiability=True) → Result¶

For each candidate leaf l calculate the number of samples in which query is true:

(1)¶\[P(query|evidence) = \frac{p_q}{p_e}\]
(2)¶\[p_q = \frac{c}{N}\]
(3)¶\[c = \frac{\prod{F}}{x^{n-1}}\]

where Q is the set of variables in query, \(P_{l}\) is the set of variables that occur in l, \(F = \{v | v \in Q \wedge~v \notin P_{l}\}\) is the set of variables in the query that do not occur in l’s path, \(x = |S_{l}|\) is the number of samples in l, \(n = |F|\) is the number of free variables and N is the number of samples represented by the entire tree. reference to (1)

Parameters:

  • query (dict of {jpt.variables.Variable : jpt.learning.distributions.Distribution.value}) – the event to query for, i.e. the query part of the conditional P(query|evidence) or the prior P(query)

  • evidence (dict of {jpt.variables.Variable : jpt.learning.distributions.Distribution.value}) – the event conditioned on, i.e. the evidence part of the conditional P(query|evidence)

posterior(self, variables, evidence, fail_on_unsatisfiability=True) → PosteriorResult¶
Parameters:

  • variables (list of jpt.variables.Variable) – the query variables of the posterior to be computed

  • evidence – the evidence given for the posterior to be computed

  • fail_on_unsatisfiability (bool) – wether or not an Unsatisfiability error is raised if the likelihood of the evidence is 0.

Returns:

jpt.trees.InferenceResult containing distributions, candidates and weights

expectation(self, variables=None, evidence=None, confidence_level=None, fail_on_unsatisfiability=True) → ExpectationResult¶

Compute the expected value of all variables. If no variables are passed, it defaults to all variables not passed as evidence.

mpe(self, evidence=None, fail_on_unsatisfiability=True) → MPEResult¶

Compute the (conditional) MPE state of the model.

_prepropress_query(self, query, transform_values=True, remove_none=True) → jpt.variables.VariableMap¶

Transform a query entered by a user into an internal representation that can be further processed.

c45(self, data, start, end, parent, child_idx, depth) → None¶

Creates a node in the decision tree according to the C4.5 algorithm on the data identified by indices. The created node is put as a child with index child_idx to the children of node parent, if any.

Parameters:

  • data – the indices for the training samples used to calculate the gain.

  • start – the starting index in the data.

  • end – the stopping index in the data.

  • parent – the parent node of the current iteration, initially None.

  • child_idx – the index of the child in the current iteration.

  • depth – the depth of the tree in the current recursion level.

pfmt(self) → str¶

Return a pretty-format string representation of this JPT.

_preprocess_data(self, data=None, rows=None, columns=None) → numpy.ndarray¶

Transform the input data into an internal representation.

learn(self, data=None, rows=None, columns=None) → JPT¶

Fits the data into a regression tree.

Parameters:

  • data ([[str or float or bool]]; (according to self.variables)) – The training examples (assumed in row-shape)

  • rows ([[str or float or bool]]; (according to self.variables)) – The training examples (assumed in row-shape)

  • columns ([[str or float or bool]]; (according to self.variables)) – The training examples (assumed in row-shape)

likelihood(self, queries: numpy.ndarray, durac_scaling=2.0, min_distances=None) → numpy.ndarray¶

Get the probabilities of a list of worlds. The worlds must be fully assigned with single numbers (no intervals).

Parameters:

  • queries (np.array) – An array containing the worlds. The shape is (x, len(variables)).

  • durac_scaling (float) – the minimal distance between the samples within a dimension are multiplied by this factor if a durac impulse is used to model the variable.

  • min_distances (Dict[Variable, float]) – A dict mapping the variables to the minimal distances between the observations. This can be useful to use the same likelihood parameters for different test sets for example in cross validation processes.

Returns: An np.array with shape (x, ) containing the probabilities.

reverse(self, query, confidence=0.5) → List[Tuple[Dict, List[Node]]]¶

Determines the leaf nodes that match query best and returns their respective paths to the root node.

Parameters:

  • query (dict) – a mapping from featurenames to either numeric value intervals or an iterable of categorical values

  • confidence (float) – the confidence level for this MPE inference

Returns:

a mapping from probabilities to lists of matcalo.core.algorithms.JPT.Node (path to root)

Return type:

dict

plot(self, title=None, filename=None, directory='/tmp', plotvars=None, view=True, max_symb_values=10)¶

Generates an SVG representation of the generated regression tree.

Parameters:

  • title – (str) title of the plot

  • filename (str) – the name of the JPT (will also be used as filename; extension will be added automatically)

  • directory (str) – the location to save the SVG file to

  • plotvars (<jpt.variables.Variable>) – the variables to be plotted in the graph

  • view (bool) – whether the generated SVG file will be opened automatically

  • max_symb_values – limit the maximum number of symbolic values to this number

pickle(self, fpath) → None¶

Pickles the fitted regression tree to a file at the given location fpath.

Parameters:

fpath (str) – the location for the pickled file

static load(fpath)¶

Loads the pickled regression tree from the file at the given location fpath.

Parameters:

fpath (str) – the location of the pickled file

static calcnorm(sigma, mu, intervals)¶

Computes the CDF for a multivariate normal distribution.

Parameters:

  • sigma (float) – the standard deviation

  • mu (float) – the expected value

  • intervals (list of matcalo.utils.utils.Interval) – the boundaries of the integral

conditional_jpt(self, evidence: jpt.variables.VariableMap, keep_evidence: bool = False)¶

Apply evidence on a JPT and get a new JPT that represent P(x|evidence). The new JPT contains all variables that are not in the evidence and is a full joint probability distribution over those variables.

Parameters:

  • evidence (VariableMap) – A variable Map mapping the observed variables to there observed, single values (not intervals)

  • keep_evidence (bool) – Rather to keep the evidence variables in the new JPT or not. If kept, their PDFs are replaced with Durac impulses.

save(self, file) → None¶

Write this JPT persistently to disk.

file can be either a string or file-like object.

static load(file)¶

Load a JPT from disk.
